body: This is similar to KAFKA-2735 (#415) and KAFKA-2272. This looks good to me, but we should make sure their aren't more cases of this. It would be great to consolidate the common regex's, and write a unit test or two as well. I'm not opposed to that being in a separate jira.
Definitely, I thought KAFKA-2757 was for that (it should probably mention the regex under `Utils` too.
I think the current intent is to use KAFKA_HEAP_OPTS, KAFKA_JVM_PERFORMANCE_OPTS, KAFKA_GC_LOG_OPTS, and KAFKA_JMX_OPTS for your java options. Is it feasible to use those instead of adding a new one?

Thanks @ymatsuda , I will close this PR and open another one for a broader review.

This PR is only for the public interface and there is no real implementations yet (all marked as TODOs), the Jenkins job will expect to fail so do not worry about that. Ping @jkreps @nehanarkhede @junrao @gwenshap @miguno @ewencp @ijuma @ymatsuda for reviews.

A brief summary of the design:
- We add a KWindowedTable as a third citizen in addition to KStream and KTable, which can be generated either from windowed stream-stream join or stream aggregations (which must be windowed as well). The main reasons for adding this interface are the following:

a. Windowed tables generated from a windowing definition cannot be directly written back to a Kafka topic: users have to decide either encode the window id into the key or value.

b. We want to support a specific left join for windowed tables that allow shifting windows when joining two windowed tables, e.g. comparing the current aggregate results with history windowed aggregates a week ago.

c. Stream to windowed-table join needs to be handled differently from stream to table join.

Admittedly adding this third class makes the whole DSL a bit too fat and cumbersome. So feedbacks and thoughts on tangling the above three issues in order to simplify the APIs are more than welcomed.
- Operations that generates a KTable or KWindowedTable needs to specify a table name.

This is because for such operations we need to create a local state store with a Kafka change log, the table name will then be used as the change log topic name; this name cannot be auto-generated since topology changes may modify the ordering and hence mess up the change logs upon job restarts (we want to maintain such change logs across multiple runs so the topic names must be unique).

This might be another user burden, so better ideas are welcomed.
- (Windowed) Aggregates on KStreams must be on the message key, while Aggregates on KTables will specify a KeySelector to select the aggregate key. We expect users to first use map() on KStreams to get the new key as the aggregate key if it was not before.
- We define inner / outer / leftJoins, and restrict only a subset of them for KStream-KStream, KStream-KTable, KTable-KTable and KWindowedTable-KWindowedTable joins because we feel these are the most common join scenarios. Please let me know if you feel other join cases may also be common.

Also for KWindowedTable-KWindowedTable joins we requires the two tables' window definition to be the same, i.e. they must be the same window type (sliding, hopping, etc) that can be aligned (with same window boundaries).

But KAFKA_OPTS is useful for this purpose, so I will close this PR.

Thanks for the PR, can you please change the PR title to match our convention?

"The PR title should usually be of the form KAFKA-xxxx: Title, where KAFKA-xxxx is the relevant JIRA id and Title may be the JIRA's title or a more specific title describing the PR itself. For trivial cases where a JIRA is not required (see JIRA section for more details) MINOR: or HOTFIX: can be used as the PR title prefix."

Above copied from https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Contributing+Code+Changes

@junrao I changed log.cleaner.delete.retention.ms to 7 days to match the default log.retention time. I thought this would cause less "surprise" since the default SLA for "not missing any data" would then be the same between topics with cleanup.policy=delete and cleanup.policy=compact. Since removing the tombstones seamed like mostly a space saving optimization, I thought this change was fairly safe. I am happy to remove the change. Should I set it back to 1 day?

Minor improvement: The error message should probably mention that the batch expired due to timeout while requesting metadata from brokers? i.e. lets not make our users read the code comment to figure out what happened.

I was just thinking that "requesting metadata" might not be the only reason. Suppose we have inflight request set to 1 and somehow the connection between the leader and the producer has some issues (cut cable), but the broker is able to communicate with other brokers in the cluster, so the metadata refresh still returns this broker as the leader. 
The batches sent on wire will be timed out and retried until the max retries. In the mean time, the other batches in the RecordAccumulator might expire due to timeout.
Should be noted that overflow is technically still possible in this patch, but the cluster size would have to be greater than Integer.MAX_VALUE/2 to see it.
The commits seem to be for a different issue than the one described in the PR.

I think in the grand scheme of things `--version` is a better flag. I just wanted to bring up for discussion the fact that there are single `-` versions of long arguments right now too (e.g., `-daemon`, `-name`, etc.)

Another question though -- it looks like there's still at least one case of a star import:

```
$ git grep ^import | grep \*
core/src/main/scala/kafka/tools/KafkaMigrationTool.java:import joptsimple.*;
```

But it isn't being caught. I'm guessing this because it is actually under the scala directory (despite being a java file) and checkstyle simply isn't checking files under that directory? It does seem like other star imports are being caught if I add them.

@ewencp - I tried to add checktyle to core module build. and found numerous checkstyle errors for existing java code.  For reference, pls see checkstyle report attached to jira ticket - https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12778864/main.xml

Of these errors, this one seems most significant - "Import control file does not handle this package". Essentially, we need to define a new import control file (or update existing one) for package - "kafka" under core module.

So, what would you like me to do here?

My suggestion is - 
1) fix the original issue for non-core modules. (I can raise new pull request incorporating your review comment).
2) create separate jira ticket to apply checkstyle rules to core module and fix violations (or add subtasks to existing ticket KAFKA-2787 created by @granthenke ).

Thoughts?

This is just replicating original patch that @harshach posted. Given I had to make MetadataCache public I am not sure if this is acceptable. I can change the code so as part stopReplica request we will also remove all the groups associated with the topic if others feel that is a better way to handle this.
@ijuma Updated the doc line
We should update the wiki too once this PR is merged: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Patch+submission+and+review
@hachikuji, what are your thoughts?

Seems reasonable overall, though it's unfortunate that GroupMetadataManager now has to depend on MetadataCache. Perhaps it's justifiable. We could even move some of the topic existence checks in KafkaApis into GroupMetadataManager, though I'm not sure that's a good idea. 

One question is whether there are any compatibility concerns since we are deleting offsets prior to the expiration of the retention time which is provided in the OffsetCommitRequest? Technically commits remain fetchable currently even after a topic has been deleted, though it seems very unlikely that anyone is depending on that. But since the default retention is 24 hours, I'm wondering if there is really a strong reason to delete before then?

@hachikuji I think the rationale is to try and cleanup all things that are related to a topic in any way as soon as the topic is deleted to avoid any confusion , this probably becomes more important if the topic is recreated. 

If there is actually no concern around keeping this data around for 24 hours even though the source (topic itself) is deleted we can just close the jira as won't fix and I am fine with that approach too.

@Parth-Brahmbhatt I don't have a strong preference either way. Deleting committed offsets on topic deletion makes sense to me, but I wouldn't consider it a major problem if it was left around for the full retention period either. Mostly I was curious about the expectations for the user. If they delete the topic and recreate it immediately, would they expect that commit data to be gone? Obviously in this patch, it may or may not be. It could even be only partially deleted. So if it's not really something that the user can depend on, then maybe there's not a whole lot of value in deleting before the expiration of the retention period. It might help if the JIRA included a little more detail on this point.
Thanks.

@hachikuji @Parth-Brahmbhatt I don't think anyone should rely on topic commit offsets to be available after topic deletion. It exists right now because we didn't address this JIRA for 0.9 release. A topic deletion should remove any associated metadata with it as well.  On other side if the topic deleted and recreated and consumers with same group.id will not be fetching data as there is an offset associated with it still exists, which is in a way not a desired behavior either. Also this JIRA is the reason we didn't set delete.topic.enable to true by default, as having consumer offsets available is not idle behavior incase of deletion.

@harshach That makes sense to me. So I wonder if instead of piggybacking on top of the expiration cron, we should add a `deleteOffsetsByTopic(topic)` method to GroupMetadataManager which is invoked explicitly on topic deletion? Then users would be able to depend on offsets being deleted after topic deletion. For whatever it's worth, that would also get around the need to make MetadataCache public.
@hachikuji that is what I was proposing originally "I can change the code so as part StopReplica request we will also remove all the groups associated with the topic"
@hachikuji @Parth-Brahmbhatt that approach sounds right to me
@hachikuji A bunch of small questions, but overall this looks like a nice cleanup and extension. All the affected tests are passing cleanly for me here.
@ijuma @hachikuji this is now in good shape, I added some details in the issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3006
@granthenke LGTM, merged with minor tweak to remove unused imports in the import-control-core.xml.
